elements.content: A novel 24-niobic-2-tellurite, [H2Te2Nb24O72]14–, was isolated by incorporating tellurite anions into a polyoxoniobate cage. The synthesized cluster represents the first example of a sandwich-type polyoxoniobate with the largest telluroniobate aggregate. Furthermore, the hybrid material acts as an efficient catalyst for the decolorization of basic fuchsin.
elements.clean_text: A novel 24-niobic-2-tellurite, [H2Te2Nb24O72]14-, was isolated by incorporating tellurite anions into a polyoxoniobate cage. The synthesized cluster represents the first example of a sandwich-type polyoxoniobate with the largest telluroniobate aggregate. Furthermore, the hybrid material acts as an efficient catalyst for the decolorization of basic fuchsin.

elements.content: A novel tellurniobate species, [H2Te2Nb24O72]14−, was prepared that can be seen as a niobium cage containing two pyramidal {TeO3} groups. Alternatively, six Nb atoms are sandwiched between two {TeNb9}. This represents the largest telluroniobate aggreate and the first hexaniobate sandwich-type polyoxometalate. Furthermore, this compound exhibits activity for the decolorization of basic fuchsin.
elements.clean_text: A novel tellurniobate species, [H2Te2Nb24O72]14-, was prepared that can be seen as a niobium cage containing two pyramidal {TeO3} groups. Alternatively, six Nb atoms are sandwiched between two {TeNb9}. This represents the largest telluroniobate aggreate and the first hexaniobate sandwich-type polyoxometalate. Furthermore, this compound exhibits activity for the decolorization of basic fuchsin.

elements.content: Heteropolyoxometalates (HPOMs) are well-known because of their wide range of tunable electronic and physical properties, which result in their extensive use in catalysis, materials science, and even in medicine. Its important to select heteroanion templates for the synthesis and structural isolation of HPOMs, which might play an important role in obtaining novel molecules. In polyoxotungstates, several excellent researches explored whether a redox-active heteroanion (TeO3 2–) was effective in templating diverse structures in the self-assembly process. However, heteropolyniobate (HPON) chemistry, one set of HPOMs, remains relatively unexplored compared to their close periodic neighbors W, Mo, and V. In fact, after Nyman’s initial discovery in 2002, some more compounds based upon “conventional” heteroanion templates (e.g., SiO4 4–, PO4 3–, GeO4 4–, and AsO4 3–) have been reported, mostly with a niobate Keggin framework (Figure S1). In contrast, the heteroanion (TeO3 2–) with a lone pair of electrons embedded in HPON has not yet been reported. Thus, it is possible to generate fascinating HPON architectures whereby the structures are directed by the tellurite anions.
elements.clean_text: Heteropolyoxometalates (HPOMs) are well-known because of their wide range of tunable electronic and physical properties, which result in their extensive use in catalysis, materials science, and even in medicine. Its important to select heteroanion templates for the synthesis and structural isolation of HPOMs, which might play an important role in obtaining novel molecules. In polyoxotungstates, several excellent researches explored whether a redox-active heteroanion (TeO3 2-) was effective in templating diverse structures in the self-assembly process. However, heteropolyniobate (HPON) chemistry, one set of HPOMs, remains relatively unexplored compared to their close periodic neighbors W, Mo, and V. In fact, after Nyman's initial discovery in 2002, some more compounds based upon "conventional" heteroanion templates (e.g., SiO4 4-, PO4 3-, GeO4 4-, and AsO4 3-) have been reported, mostly with a niobate Keggin framework (Figure S1). In contrast, the heteroanion (TeO3 2-) with a lone pair of electrons embedded in HPON has not yet been reported. Thus, it is possible to generate fascinating HPON architectures whereby the structures are directed by the tellurite anions.

elements.content: Besides this, disposal of organic dyes is a matter of serious concern because of their poor biodegradation, toxicity, and unsightliness. In recent years, polyoxometalates have emerged as potential catalysts in the degradation of organic dyes. It is thus meaningful to explore a heterogeneous system with good recyclability.
elements.clean_text: Besides this, disposal of organic dyes is a matter of serious concern because of their poor biodegradation, toxicity, and unsightliness. In recent years, polyoxometalates have emerged as potential catalysts in the degradation of organic dyes. It is thus meaningful to explore a heterogeneous system with good recyclability.

elements.content: Herein, we report a novel 24-Nb–O cage encapsulating two pyramidal [TeIVO3]2– templates: [H2Te2Nb24O72]14– (1a) isolated as K4[{Cu­(en)2(H2O)}4{Cu­(en)2}­(H2Te2Nb24O72)]·8H2O (1), which represents the first example of a telluirum-containing sandwich-type HPON with an unprecedented hexaniobium ring in the sandwiched sites (a). It is worth noting that 1 catalyzed the decolorization of basic fuchsin (BF) and could be isolated for reuse.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a novel 24-Nb-O cage encapsulating two pyramidal [TeIVO3]2- templates: [H2Te2Nb24O72]14- (1a) isolated as K4[{Cu(en)2(H2O)}4{Cu(en)2}(H2Te2Nb24O72)]⋅8H2O (1), which represents the first example of a telluirum-containing sandwich-type HPON with an unprecedented hexaniobium ring in the sandwiched sites (a). It is worth noting that 1 catalyzed the decolorization of basic fuchsin (BF) and could be isolated for reuse.

elements.content: (a) Ball-and-stick representation of 1a. (b) Polyhedral and ball-and-stick representations of two [TeNb9O33]17– fragments. (c) Side view of [Nb6O24]18–. (d) Top view of the large cavity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Ball-and-stick representation of 1a. (b) Polyhedral and ball-and-stick representations of two [TeNb9O33]17- fragments. (c) Side view of [Nb6O24]18-. (d) Top view of the large cavity.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized from an alkaline mixture of K7HNb6O19·13H2O with TeO2 to which copper amine cations were subsequently added. The phase purity of 1 was characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S6). The unprecedented 24-niobic-2-tellurite polyanion presents four interesting remarkable features: (1) it is the largest telluroniobate aggregate isolated so far among the existing HPON family; (2) the {TeNb9} building block is observed for the first time; (3) six Nb atoms occupy the “belt” positions, displaying a chair-conformation-like cyclohexane; (4) it represents the first example of a hexaniobium sandwich-type polyoxometalate.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was synthesized from an alkaline mixture of K7HNb6O19⋅13H2O with TeO2 to which copper amine cations were subsequently added. The phase purity of 1 was characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S6). The unprecedented 24-niobic-2-tellurite polyanion presents four interesting remarkable features: (1) it is the largest telluroniobate aggregate isolated so far among the existing HPON family; (2) the {TeNb9} building block is observed for the first time; (3) six Nb atoms occupy the "belt" positions, displaying a chair-conformation-like cyclohexane; (4) it represents the first example of a hexaniobium sandwich-type polyoxometalate.

elements.content: A detailed crystallographic analysis reveals that 1a consists of two B-α-[TeNb9O33]17– (TeNb 9 ) subunits and a central distorted ring shape [Nb6O24]18–. The core TeNb 9 is derived from the self-assembly of TeO2 and [Nb6O19]8–, where a Te atom links to three O atoms from the edge-shared triad of NbO6 octahedra, respectively. The [TeO3]2– ions, with a lone pair of electrons acting as heteroanion templates, bonded to three O atoms in a trigonal configuration, effectively giving rise to “open” lacunary units instead of “closed” Keggin-type clusters. Besides, because of the large radius of Te4+, the two TeNb 9 building blocks are hindered upon joining together. The TeNb 9 subunit is observed in a polyoxoniobate (PON) for the first time, although it is common in polyoxotungstate. It is noted that two TeNb 9 subunits are linked by Nb–O bridges in a face-to-face manner, with a “half-unit” rotating by about 60° (b). The slight difference lowers the symmetry of 1a from D 3h to C 3v . Also, the heteroatoms are located on a crystallographic 3-fold axis with a Te···Te (virtual) distance of 5.1273(10) Å. The metallaring-type moiety, [Nb6O24]18–, is a hinge chelating to two TeNb 9 ligands (c), in which six Nb atoms are connected in an orderly model, giving rise to an intriguing chair configuration if all of the O atoms are omitted (Figure S2). Alternatively, six NbO6 moieties match extremely well with the structure of the crown ether 18-crown-6 (Figure S3). In this way, compound 1 represents the first member of sandwich-type tellurium-containing PON, interestingly differing from the traditional sandwich type in the sandwiched sites. Given the six equatorial Nb atoms, 1a can also be seen as a niobium cage embedding in two pyramidal tellurite anions [TeO3]2– with an average Te–O distance of 1.86 Å. Furthermore, the linkages among Nb, O, and Te atoms create an oval cavity (d), as reflected by a deviation of ca. 1.5 Å between the “length” of 6.6 Å (radius of the O center in the plane of three Nb centers and one Nb atom) and the “width” of 5.1 Å (diameter of opposite Te centers perpendicular to the previous plane). Therefore, the compound is also the second but largest telluroniobate aggregate in the literature to date.
elements.clean_text: A detailed crystallographic analysis reveals that 1a consists of two B-α-[TeNb9O33]17- (TeNb  9 ) subunits and a central distorted ring shape [Nb6O24]18-. The core TeNb  9  is derived from the self-assembly of TeO2 and [Nb6O19]8-, where a Te atom links to three O atoms from the edge-shared triad of NbO6 octahedra, respectively. The [TeO3]2- ions, with a lone pair of electrons acting as heteroanion templates, bonded to three O atoms in a trigonal configuration, effectively giving rise to "open" lacunary units instead of "closed" Keggin-type clusters. Besides, because of the large radius of Te4+, the two TeNb  9  building blocks are hindered upon joining together. The TeNb  9  subunit is observed in a polyoxoniobate (PON) for the first time, although it is common in polyoxotungstate. It is noted that two TeNb  9  subunits are linked by Nb-O bridges in a face-to-face manner, with a "half-unit" rotating by about 60° (b). The slight difference lowers the symmetry of 1a from D 3h  to C 3v . Also, the heteroatoms are located on a crystallographic 3-fold axis with a Te⋅⋅⋅Te (virtual) distance of 5.1273(10) Å. The metallaring-type moiety, [Nb6O24]18-, is a hinge chelating to two TeNb  9  ligands (c), in which six Nb atoms are connected in an orderly model, giving rise to an intriguing chair configuration if all of the O atoms are omitted (Figure S2). Alternatively, six NbO6 moieties match extremely well with the structure of the crown ether 18-crown-6 (Figure S3). In this way, compound 1 represents the first member of sandwich-type tellurium-containing PON, interestingly differing from the traditional sandwich type in the sandwiched sites. Given the six equatorial Nb atoms, 1a can also be seen as a niobium cage embedding in two pyramidal tellurite anions [TeO3]2- with an average Te-O distance of 1.86 Å. Furthermore, the linkages among Nb, O, and Te atoms create an oval cavity (d), as reflected by a deviation of ca. 1.5 Å between the "length" of 6.6 Å (radius of the O center in the plane of three Nb centers and one Nb atom) and the "width" of 5.1 Å (diameter of opposite Te centers perpendicular to the previous plane). Therefore, the compound is also the second but largest telluroniobate aggregate in the literature to date.

elements.content: In addition, copper–organic fragments have been successfully grafted onto the {Te2Nb24O72} cluster, forming a ribbon-like geometry (a); K cations sew together the strands to form a two-dimensional plane (b). The two protons should be added for charge-balance considerations and bond-valence-sum calculations. The protons maybe delocalize over the entire architecture (Table S3 and Figure S5). The formula is verified further based on different analytical methods, namely, elemental analysis (C, H, and N), IR, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and UV–vis (Figures S7–S10).
elements.clean_text: In addition, copper-organic fragments have been successfully grafted onto the {Te2Nb24O72} cluster, forming a ribbon-like geometry (a); K cations sew together the strands to form a two-dimensional plane (b). The two protons should be added for charge-balance considerations and bond-valence-sum calculations. The protons maybe delocalize over the entire architecture (Table S3 and Figure S5). The formula is verified further based on different analytical methods, namely, elemental analysis (C, H, and N), IR, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and UV-vis (Figures S7-S10).

elements.content: One-dimensional (a) and two-dimensional (b) frameworks of 1.

The ability of 1 to catalyze the decolorization of BF was studied. In a blank experiment, the decolorization rate of a BF solution was only 4.59% for 1 h. The decolorization rate can achieve 92.35% by the addition of 1.6 × 10–5 mol of 1 (a,b). Subsequently, if the addition of 1 was increased to 2.4 × 10–5 mol, (C 0 – C t )/C 0 was a little lower than that of 1.6 × 10–5 mol, indicating that the optimal dosage was 1.6 × 10–5 mol (c and S12). In contrast, when the above reaction was carried out in the presence of either [Cu­(en)2]2+ or TeO2, C t /C 0 was found to be around 1, thereby clearly confirming the active catalyst for the decolorization of our compound, while the decolorization rate of a BF solution using Nb2O5 was 28.38% for 1 h (Figure S13). Meanwhile, comparative experiments were further performed by using K7HNb6O19·13H2O, which was completely soluble in our reaction medium, although it has a catalytic effect on BF. The insolubility nature of 1 is of great importance because it allows the catalyst to be recovered and reused for several consecutive reaction runs.

The decolorization rate can achieve 92.35% by the addition of 1.6 × 10-5 mol of 1 (a,b). Subsequently, if the addition of 1 was increased to 2.4 × 10-5 mol, (C 0 - C  t )/C 0 was a little lower than that of 1.6 × 10-5 mol, indicating that the optimal dosage was 1.6 × 10-5 mol (c and S12). In contrast, when the above reaction was carried out in the presence of either [Cu(en)2]2+ or TeO2, C  t /C 0 was found to be around 1, thereby clearly confirming the active catalyst for the decolorization of our compound, while the decolorization rate of a BF solution using Nb2O5 was 28.38% for 1 h (Figure S13). Meanwhile, comparative experiments were further performed by using K7HNb6O19⋅13H2O, which was completely soluble in our reaction medium, although it has a catalytic effect on BF. The insolubility nature of 1 is of great importance because it allows the catalyst to be recovered and reused for several consecutive reaction runs.

elements.content: (a) Absorption spectra of a BF aqueous solution in the presence of compound 1 (1.63 × 10–5 mol). (b) Conversion of BF (K) with the reaction time (t) of 1. The conversion of BF (K) can be expressed as K = (C 0 – C t )/C 0, where C 0 represents the UV intensity of BF at the initial time (t = 0) and the UV absorption intensity at a given time (t). (c) Plot of C t /C 0 of BF versus time with different usage amounts of 1. (d) Five recycles of the decolorization of BF.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Absorption spectra of a BF aqueous solution in the presence of compound 1 (1.63 × 10-5 mol). (b) Conversion of BF (K) with the reaction time (t) of 1. The conversion of BF (K) can be expressed as K = (C 0 - C  t )/C 0, where C 0 represents the UV intensity of BF at the initial time (t = 0) and the UV absorption intensity at a given time (t). (c) Plot of C  t /C 0 of BF versus time with different usage amounts of 1. (d) Five recycles of the decolorization of BF.

elements.content: The recyclability of the catalyst system was also tested, and the results show that it could be recycled at least five times with a small gradual decline in yield to 92.35%, 81.54%, 73.68%, 75.38%, and 68.46% (d). The slight decline corresponded to the loss of catalyst. Interestingly, the PXRD patterns and IR spectra are nearly identical before and after five cycles of catalysis (Figures S14 and S15). Thus, it is concluded that 1 has good repeatability, with remarkable stability in the present experimental conditions. Further catalytic tests of 1 for different organic dyes concluded the exclusive selectively of 1 toward the decolorization of BF (Table S5).
elements.clean_text: The recyclability of the catalyst system was also tested, and the results show that it could be recycled at least five times with a small gradual decline in yield to 92.35%, 81.54%, 73.68%, 75.38%, and 68.46% (d). The slight decline corresponded to the loss of catalyst. Interestingly, the PXRD patterns and IR spectra are nearly identical before and after five cycles of catalysis (Figures S14 and S15). Thus, it is concluded that 1 has good repeatability, with remarkable stability in the present experimental conditions. Further catalytic tests of 1 for different organic dyes concluded the exclusive selectively of 1 toward the decolorization of BF (Table S5).

elements.content: TGA after the catalytic experiment indicates that the total weight loss from room temperature to 1250 °C was 24.01%, which was in accordance with the theoretical value (23.39%) and the value of fresh sample (23.14%; Figure S16). Further, elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of compound 1 in different conditions were measured (Table S6). Calcd: H, 2.17; C, 4.87; N, 5.68. Found (crystal): H, 2.28; C, 4.72; N, 5.57. Found (catalyzed sample): H, 2.12; C, 4.99; N, 5.40. Therefore, compound 1 is decolorizing the dye, not adsorbing.

Found (catalyzed sample): H, 2.12; C, 4.99; N, 5.40. Therefore, compound 1 is decolorizing the dye, not adsorbing.

elements.content: In summary, an unprecedented hexaniobium sandwich-type HPON directed by a [TeO3]2– ion has been synthesized. Compound 1 represents the first member of a tellurium-containing sandwich-type HPON and the largest telluroniobate aggregate. The isolation shows that the TeIV ions in 1 serve as templates to the key building units, thereby enabling the self-assembly of trivacant TeNb 9 . The activity of 1 indicates that it can be regarded as a potential catalyst in the decolorization of BF. In future work, we will explore more novel clusters with [TeO3]2– as the template as well as perform catalytic studies.
elements.clean_text: In summary, an unprecedented hexaniobium sandwich-type HPON directed by a [TeO3]2- ion has been synthesized. Compound 1 represents the first member of a tellurium-containing sandwich-type HPON and the largest telluroniobate aggregate. The isolation shows that the TeIV ions in 1 serve as templates to the key building units, thereby enabling the self-assembly of trivacant TeNb  9 . The activity of 1 indicates that it can be regarded as a potential catalyst in the decolorization of BF. In future work, we will explore more novel clusters with [TeO3]2- as the template as well as perform catalytic studies.

These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033.

elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Synthesis of 1: The procedure involves the formation of two solutions. Solution A comprises K7H[Nb6O19]·13H2O (0.33 g, 0.24 mmol) and TeO2 (0.04 g, 0.25 mmol) in distilled water (8.33 mL). Meanwhile, in a separate beaker, ethanediamine (0.21 mL) was added to a stirred clear solution of CuCl2·2H2O (0.17 g, 1.00 mmol) in water (0.83 mL), yielding solution B. Solution B was added directly into solution A. The pH was adjusted to 11.90 using KOH (2 mol·L–1). The resulting mixture was stirred for 15 min, sealed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave, kept at 160 °C for 4 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Black block crystals were obtained by filtering, washed with distilled water, and dried in air. Yield: 20% based on K7H[Nb6O19]·13H2O. Elem anal. Calcd for C20H106Cu5K4N20Te2Nb24O84: H, 2.17; C, 4.87; N, 5.68. Found: H, 2.28; C, 4.72; N, 5.57. IR (KBr): 3265, 1585, 1051, 893, 857, 771, 736, 669, 593, 537, 465 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Further, elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of compound 1 in different conditions were measured (Table S6). Calcd: H, 2.17; C, 4.87; N, 5.68. Found (crystal): H, 2.28; C, 4.72; N, 5.57. Found (catalyzed sample): H, 2.12; C, 4.99; N, 5.40. Therefore, compound 1 is decolorizing the dye, not adsorbing.
